description.text:
(Check out the derivative thing which I find works better)
Trying to sort out the mess of cables on my desk. The name is a reflection on the shape of the hub, which is the result of trying to maximize the bending radius of the cable.
Of course the OpenSCAD sources are fully parametric but comments are lacking...
Update: Updated scad file before first print to reduce overhangs on the lid.
Update2: Made two of these spools now, and not entirely satisfied... This design is too weak to work well with less flexible cables. Also, unwinding is a pain because the cable tends to unwind inside the spool making it jam. Next, I will try a detachable lid that snaps over the cable.

Print lid and base, snap together. A quick sanding and some grease makes it turn smoothly. Stls are tuned for walls of two perimeters thickness and an extrusion width of 0.48 mm. Rather thin but works quite well
To insert cable, line up the lid so that the cable can be inserted through the center. Hold the outside and wind by inserting thumb and index finger of your other hand in the openings in the center part and twist.

print_settings.Notes:: Note it is your responsibility to safely colorize the flash hider an appropriate shade of safety orange.

description.text:
We all enjoy firing our Nerf Apollo blasters, whether in an active war zone or just during a casual day at the range. But if we're honest, the muzzle flash from a stock Apollo can be disorienting at best--lethally distracting at worst. That's why SlightlyOddGuy Industries has worked tirelessly to deliver you the very best in flash-reducing technology!

Introducing the SlightlyOdd Flash Hider, the newest in the Apollo-compatible line of muzzle attachments! Using state-of-the-art CAD software, SlightlyOddGuy Industries has designed the perfect solution to completely rid yourself of temporary operator blindness! The SlightlyOdd Barrel Adapter is also included with this product--compatible with all SlightlyOdd muzzle attachments! As if that's not enough, solid construction and extra muzzle mass also aid in reducing muzzle climb. Beat those numbers, Verizon!

If you've enjoyed this product, you might consider checking out our other Nerf-compatible products!

Printer Brand:

LulzBot

Printer:

Mini

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.25ish

Infill:

20-30%

Notes:

Since no gluing should be required due to the nature of the tight-tolerance fit, ABS or PLA is ok.

  1. Remove outer casing of Apollo blaster.

  2. Replace OEM orange barrel with barrel adapter.

  3. Reassemble Apollo blaster and install flash hider. Some sanding may be required to knock the burrs off the edge.

  4. Enjoy the looks on envy from other Nerf owners.

Note it is your responsibility to safely colorize the flash hider an appropriate shade of safety orange.

print_settings.Notes:: First, make this out of ABS, it'll be much easier.

description.text:
Sick and tired of not having a comfortable grip on your Nerf Apollo? Do you feel like the harsh edges of the blaster are hard on your baby-smooth hands? Are you yearning for some more leverage against the powerful recoil the Apollo produces? If you said "yes!" to any of these questions, the Nerf-compatible SlightlyOdd Foregrip is just for you.

SlightlyOddGuy Industries craves solving the problems we all deal with on a daily basis, and the Apollo foregrip issue has been at the top of our list for a long time. The SlightlyOdd Foregrip presents a solidly designed, solidly coupled piece of hardware. With two points of attachment to the Apollo, the only way this product is coming off is if you break your blaster into pieces with a similarly sturdy object, like a sledgehammer or a backhoe.

Like what you see here? Check out our other Nerf-compatible products!

Printer:

Yes

20-30%

Notes:

  1. First, make this out of ABS, it'll be much easier.

  2. Second, you'll want to disassemble your blaster to get at that orange tab on the triggerguard.

  3. Once you have everything apart, go ahead and insert the new tab into the foregrip. At this point you can put it all back together again.

  4. Then, install the foregrip onto the foregrip support.

  5. From here, you'll want to glue the exposed tab onto the foregrip. If you take a look at the pictures, you should get a good idea of what's going on.

  6. Adjust the foregrip support/glue as needed for the sturdiest configuration.

title: Hypercube Evolution X Carriage back for 8x10mm bushings

description.text:
The bearing clamps on my Hypercube Evolution snapped, so I glued the bushing adapters in place with CA glue as a last resort measure. For some reason it became significantly quieter, so now I'm printing this x carriage I drew some time ago for use with plain bearings with 10mm outer diameter such as the aliexpress bronze bushings or some teflon lined steel bushings. Lets see how it goes.

The holes are a bit too small, so you remove some material with a rotary tool or a rolled up piece of sand paper and then press-fit the bronze bushings with a piece of M8 threaded rod, two nuts and two washers.

Slides really well without binding once it's in the gantry.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ITGXa5o41Qs

For use with these bushings, but the shorter ones should work as well.

https://pt.aliexpress.com/item/SF-1-0815-Oilless-bush-DU-Self-lubricating-bushing-Sintered-bush-Size-8-10-15mm/32718123143.html

description.text: this is a black panther keychain.

My version of the Bryar pistol from the Star Wars Dark Forces video game I had grown up playing. I have taken liberties in the details and some of the shaping to suite my tastes. I have posted that it is a remix of xizor's Bryar Pistol because I imported his work into Fusion 360 for scale and some rough outlining before doing an almost complete re-CAD.

I have included the pistol as multiple parts as well as a single unit. I have also included the STEP file of the CAD for others to utilize.

This was a weekend project (That spanned a week) so I did not give much work into making a moving trigger or installing lights. It was meant to be a wall hangar and nothing more but if anyone wants to expand on the work and take it further, by all means please indulge and post.

Printed at 0.2mm layer height on my custom E-bot printer utilizing black PETG. The pistol is large and I was only able to print it on my E-bot (360 x 320mm bed). You will probably need to open the STEP file and break it into more pieces for most printers.

It was painted with filler primer, then Rustoleum metallic spray paints. Weathered with acrylics and detailed using paint pens (ie. Sharpies) of various colors.

In this new version the path to the hotend is shortened. This allows shorter distance retracts for cleaner dual color printing. The insides are the same for the most part the big difference is that the path for the filament once it passes the switch point is no longer an element in the part. Now the filament goes directly into the PTFE tube of the hot end.

See old version for more details https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1494026

description.text:
I have a small problem with my heat bed connection on the TEVO Tornado. As the heat bed moves back and forth along the Y axis, the cable moves side to side twisting the connections. After several hundred hours of printing, the problem grew big enough to render the thermistor cable unstable enough to create a MINTEMP BED error.

So I created this clip to prevent the cable from moving side to side so badly.

This is sized so it fits snugly on the stock TEVO Tornado bed with the TEVO Tornado logo pad attached.

The top piece is: 35.1mm w x 70.3mm long x 15.6mm high.
The bottom is: 34.9 mm w x 83mm long x 11.5 mm high.

The bottom piece has a notch in the end for a zip tie to hold the cable firmly to the clip.

The screw holes are sized for a M3 x 20mm screws and just long enough to put on an M3 nut. Tip: Before attaching to the cable, run the screws through it once, or use M2.5 x 20mm screws as the holes printed a little snug.

remixed_from.author: dc42
remixed_from.title: Print cooling fan mount for Duet3D PCB effector

title: Delta Smart Effector Circular Fan Duct

description.text:
Quick Start

This Thing is a circular or semi-circular fan duct for use with the Duet3D
Delta Smart Effector. It consists of two parts:

  • EffectorCircularFanDuct -- This is the fan duct itself. I provide three
    variant STL files, for 180, 270, and 360 degrees of surround.
  • EffectorFanBracket -- This is a (very slightly) modified version of the
    bracket that attaches the fan to the Duet3D Delta Smart Effector.

I provide both OpenSCAD (.scad) and STL files for both parts. If you want to
simply print and go, print both the EffectorFanBracket.stl file and the
EffectorCircularFanDuct-{angle}.stl file for whatever amount of surround you
desire.

The Benchies in one of the photos illustrate what happens when printing PLA
on my printer when I use no cooling (left), the fan duct design published by
dc42 (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2467663; middle), and the 180-degree
version of this fan duct design (right). As you can see, the biggest jump in
quality comes from no cooling to cooling with dc42's fan duct design;
however, dc42's fan duct still leaves a small blemish on the Benchy's prow.
Moving to my 180-degree fan removes this final blemish. I've seen no
improvements moving up to the 270- or 360-degree versions; however, it's
possible that some prints would benefit from more than 180 degrees of duct
coverage. On the other hand, the 360-degree version is heavier and obstructs
the view of what's happening at the nozzle. I've been using the 270-degree
version.

Additional Hardware

Assembling everything will require:

  • The same two M3 screws and nuts that dc42's original fan would require to
    connect the EffectorFanBracket, 40mm fan, and EffectorCircularFanDuct. In
    theory, 16mm screws might suffice, but in practice, you may need 20mm or
    longer screws.
  • Two somewhat shorter screws (12mm or a bit longer) are optional; they can
    secure the bottom of the fan to the fan duct, slightly improving airflow
    efficiency. (No nuts are needed for these screws; they simply screw into
    the plastic.)
  • You will also, of course, require two magballs and two M3 nuts to attach
    the EffectorFanBracket to the Delta Smart Effector.

Customization

My fan is a 40x40x10mm fan. If yours is a different size, this Thing will
require adjustment. A thinner fan might work OK with a relatively minor
tweak to EffectorFanBracket so as to lower the assembly to compensate; but a
thicker fan might require adjusting the angles of both parts. A fan that's
larger or smaller than the square 40mm size, or that takes a different form
entirely (like a "blower" fan), will require still more significant changes.

If you're comfortable with OpenSCAD, you can easily customize the
EffectorCircularFanDuct.scad file in a couple of ways:

  • You can add a recycling symbol by editing the recycleNum variable on
    line 10. (See below.)
  • You can set how many degrees of arc the fan's vents cover by editing
    the ringDegrees variable on line 15.

You can adjust several other variables on lines 18-41, to make other tweaks,
such as adjusting the thickness of the shell (fanShellThickness) or where
the airflow is aimed (targetZ). In any case, if you make a change, you must
rebuild the STL file using OpenSCAD.

The STL files I provide do not include a recycle symbol, since I don't know
what materials you'll use. If you want to have a recycle symbol, you must
edit the recycleNum variable and copy the recycling_symbol.scad file from
the OpenSCAD recycling symbol library
(https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:216963) to the same directory as
EffectorCircularFanDuct.scad, then rebuild the STL file.

The EffectorFanBracket that I provide is a slight variant on dc42's design.
Although dc42's original and my fan duct should theoretically work together,
on my printer, I found that this combination caused the fan duct to droop a
bit -- enough that the 360-degree version would scrape the build plate or
part. Thus, I altered the angle of dc42's EffectorFanBracket, changing it
from 70 degrees to 74 degrees. This fixed the problem. If you need to tweak
this detail, you can do so by editing the Angle variable on line 13 of
EffectorFanBracket.scad. Alternatively, if you find that my fan duct lifts
up, you can try using dc42's original EffectorFanBracket.stl file from
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2467663.

If your hotend is shorter or longer than a standard E3D V6 (such as if you
use a Volcano hotend), you may need to tweak the EffectorFanBracket, too. I
haven't tried it, but Print cooling fan mount for Duet3D PCB effector and
E3D V6 Volcano (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2573606) might be useful.

description.text: A little two-piece shoelace tensioning device! Wind the knob to tighten your shoes quickly, press the lever to release them! It's fast, easy, cheap, and secure! Hope you enjoy it!

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

i3 MK2S

Rafts:

No

Yes

Resolution:

Better than 0.1mm is best

Infill:

As high as possible

Notes:

Use semi-flexible filament like PET or Nylon, the ratcheting mechanism requires the piece to have a certain "springiness." Also flip the outside piece upside down to reduce support structure and use a brim.

Remove print structure

Use a hobby knife to carefully cut off the brim and support structure off both pieces.

Insert inside piece into outside piece. Thread shoelace

Thread the shoelace through the spool, make sure the lace passes through the hole in the inside piece as well as the holes in the outside piece. Next, centre the tensioner in the middle of the lace and thread the lace through your shoes as normal, except starting at the top and working down. Basically thread your shoelace upside down.

Wear shoe!

Put on the shoe, hold the outside piece with one hand and turn the inside piece until the shoe is tightened to your satisfaction.

My magnetic shoelaces aren't strong enough and I talked to a podiatrist who said shoes need to have adjustable tightness anyways. Today I was riding my bike and my shoelace came undone, so I had to use [shudders] normal laces [cue dry heaving]. Three hours later I had Mind-Birthed this masterpiece! Haven't made it yet at time of writing, I'll hopefully get it done tonight. Hope you like!!!

description.text:
Winter of 2018, I created a Prusa i3 clone.
You can build this printer for $250, or less. I did, including the cost of a 1kg spool of ABS.

The frame was based off the Original Prusa MK3 frame, but fabricated from plywood laminations. I created and used router templates (and a flush trim bit) from the Prusa .dxf files.

The rest of the parts closely follow Tom Salanderer's MK2 Clone "Dolly", with some customizations for the parts I ordered from AliExpress.

My official github repo for this project is: https://github.com/bvarner/varnerized_prusa_i3
My marlin firmware repo is: https://github.com/bvarner/marlin

I'm getting what I consider absolutely ridiculously good results out of this $250 printer, when compared side-by-side to the same models printed off an Original MK2s.

My long-term goal is to iterate on this, and upgrade the electronics to build a true MK3 clone with Trinamic drivers at some point in the future. That though, will be another 'thing'. :-)

title: Pergo Standard Tripod or Camera Thumb Screw

description.text:
This is a standard thumb screw for a Tripod
14 mm head with a 1/4 #20 thread. This the right thread size for common camera mounts but you might thing wise while reaming it in the first time. Stick with it. :)

I also included a "Shorter" version, I had one camera that had a shallow mount on it.

I used PLA and it worked wonderful.
ABS is MUCH easier and seems to cut the threads better too.
Nylon might be the BEST.
Print with no supports, 100% infill, and .1 mm layer height.

When working the threads the first few times, work it in 1/8 turn, then back about 1/8 turn each time. Repeat until the screw reaches the bottom. I used a rag on the screw head to NOT cut your skin to shreds when doing this the first time! The screw head groves are awesome once this process is done. You will curse them when cleaning up the threads the first time. You will understand the first time you are screwing this in! Once you hit the bottom the first time, each time in is really smooth.

Shrek!

If you use a chainsaw, a felling wedge is a useful tool to have. It can be used to fell a tree in a particular direction, separate wood slabs if you use an Alaskan Chainsaw Mill, or keep a log from binding your chainsaw blade.

You can buy a 5.5" felling wedge for about $5. $5?!?!?1 For a piece of plastic?? That's outrageous! I'm making my own!

Don't confuse a felling wedge with a splitting wedge. Much different purpose. (If you have some steel filament be my guest.) Also different than a pitching wedge.

The store-bought ones are solid ABS. I printed mine using PETG, although PLA may be OK. ABS should work great if you like that sort of thing. 0.25 mm layers are fine, unless you really want to impress your lumberjack friends.

I've included both the cool looking triangle braced version and a solid version. Use the solid version if you're somewhat cautious. The PETG versions I printed feel really strong; I stood on them without any damage. The wedges were undamaged too.

description.text:
Playstation 4 Official Universal Media Remote (pdp)

Like countless remotes before, the battery cover for my remote was broken and then lost. Naturally, I had 2 options: buy another remote just for the tiny, plastic battery cover or print a new cover.

If you have a printer, it's a no-brainer.

Unfortunately, I could not find a single 3D model available online for the ubiquitous PS4 Remote. So, off to the CAD I went.

It took several iterations, tweaking each detail, fine-tuning as I went but I finally got something that works well and something I am proud to share.

If you have any suggestions, feel free to speak your mind. If you like the model and you want to host it yourself, please give credit. :)

I highly recommend using a 100% solid infill*. The model is small and thin, especially at the u-bend in the clasp, and a solid print keeps it strong. Out of all iterations during development, I haven't had a single one break or fail during stress-testing.

I have a Monoprice Maker Select v2.1 and it takes about 1 hour for the print, from start to finish.

*Depending on your settings and nozzle size, something like 65-75% is close enough to a solid infill
I used my caliper to measure the battery cover rabbet on the remote and drummed up a rough design in CAD. Then I tweaked and tuned the model after each print.

description.text:
This is the claw we (Null Robotics) designed for our Relic Arm for the 2017-2018 Relic Recovery season. It's accurate, and does reliable grabs. It also corrects for small amounts of error in alignment. Leaving the surface of the print smooth (rather than coating it with something that creates friction, such as plasti-dip) allows the relic to self-center when it is grabbed. The claw is asymmetric - the skinnier claw goes into the corner of the field behind the relic, and the wide one goes on the inside. Additionally, the asymmetric cuts out of the insides of the claws allow for the relic to be grabbed completely (arms and head), or just by the arms. Both grabs can carry a relic reliably, but the full grab is more so. However, grabbing by the arms is much faster and can be used for the second relic during the end game. It uses two 40-tooth Tetrix gears, and can be used with a servo on the end of an extending arm of some sort. The strength of the grab is as strong as the servo you use. I made this in OpenSCAD.

Here's it in action: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gib3fT9ozyE

author: sbeecroft

title: KTM Custom Mount for Trailtech Vapor

description.text:
I have a KTM EXC 200 2003 model and wanted to be able to mount my Traitech Vapor while maintaining the cushion that goes over the handlebar.

I do not know with confidence which other models this will fit but an educated guess is that it will work with other EXC's (like the 125) and the SX models of the same generation too. Try it out and let us know in the comments if you got it to work on your bike!

This mount attaches to the bottom of the steering column and is designed so the Trailtech is positioned just below the front fairing.
I wanted it to be hidden for a few reasons:

  1. to protect the device
  2. to keep the functionality of the cushion (which is to protect you from banging on something hard in front of you)
  3. to keep it discrete.

The shroud is loosely based on ddoto's cover but obviously it has been re purposed, I have changed the dimensions a bit and created the necessary holes at the back. The stem screws onto the lower steering column and then protrudes up just enough for the shroud to be mounted while keeping the vapor unit below the cushion.

I created it as two separate parts first of all to make them easier to print and secondly because I think the stem will be more likely to fail in which case you can re-print it and keep the shroud.

Both parts can be printed with no support.

Prusa

Printer:

i3 MK3

40%

Notes:

I printed this with 40% infill to make it extra durable and avoid vibrations.
Ideally use orange colour to make it KTM-appropriate :)

You will need a set of longer M4 x 1mm screws than the ones that came with the unit to hold the vapor unit through the stem and the shroud. You will also need a pair of I believe M6 x 1mm with appropriate washers to attach the stem to the steering column.

author: alli_b

description.text:
Since the parts printed from the original design broke on me on a regular basis (the BLTouch arm always started to warp up after a few days and finally broke) I tried to give the arm a little more stability. Also, there's an extra hole in the fan mount plate to fit https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2807706 (which is a quick remix of https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2503019) without additional drilling.

Update V1.1 (2018-03-05): There's a new mount hole at the rear top to even more simplify cable management. I've decided to not use the cable chain for now, as it seemed to twist the mount plate on movement, thus f*cking up the accuracy of the sensor. But the two extra holes on top are still good for zip ties. Also, I removed the "stabilizing" slope again and went for two 3mm holes along the mount bar. Extra walls should improve stability, and if needed one can now install M3x40 screws for extra stiffness.

Mount for a BLTouch/3DTouch auto bed leveling sensor on an Anet A6. The probe is mounted in front of the extruder carriage. The printed part replaces the original part on which the part cooling fan is mounted.

title: Nightrider Holder
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
This is a holder to keep an Ambrosia Blucon Nightrider attached to a Freestyle Libre sensor.

I don't like wearing straps around my arm (like https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2764574 ), but the Freestyle Libre adhesive tape holds very firmly to my skin, so I developed a holder, that attaches to the Libre between its adhesive tape and the sensor itself and is high enough to include the Nightrider.
As I wanted the whole thing being removeable for taking a shower, going to the pool etc., I had to design it wide enough to get the Nightrider falling out again, and the frame being removable by firmly holding the Libre to the skin while pulling the frame off.

You may download and print this for yourself and others, but you may NOT sell the prints. I would be happy, if you leave a make or a note, if you like and use it.

title: Cable wire tie bases for use with Command strips

description.text:
I made these to use with the small 3M Command strips. You could also use them with the small velcro Command strips as well. They would be nice to use in situations where you can't (or shouldn't) use standard adhesive backed cable tie bases. The plus side is that you can print these in any color or type of filament you want.

There is a horizontal and vertical base depending on your particular need or desire. Also there is a combination horizontal and vertical base with a screw hole for mounting. I am not fond of the combo base as it seems clunky.

description.text:
I designed these to use on the back of entertainment centers, computer desks, tv stands, etc. for cable management. They are designed to let cables go in any direction and be able to secure them in place. My inspiration is what would happen if you crossed a cable tie base with a cable tray.

The bottom horizontal row of holes is for screw mounting. The top row is for using these... https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:448001 along with a #4 or #6 screw. You can do it for your own needs as well. You could also mount these with double sided tape or Command strips.

This is the second version as the first one had too many issues with the fingers breaking off. I added some additional reinforcement material to solve that. They are now pretty sturdy. I am also working on an inside and outside corner version along with a tee section.

A new housing for the CR10S Filament Sensor

You need to buy x3 M3 x 16mm Cap head Hex bolts and x3 M3 nuts

When clamping down do not tighten the clamp bolts hard at all, just nip them all down its all thats needed.

Only the Body needs supports (TOUCHING PLATFORM ONLY)
When tapping the holes for the cap screws take it real slow turn screw back it out turn more back out rinse and repeat to not split the walls.

title: Superlight SOTA Vertical for 40-30-20m with Loading Coil

description.text:
This is the enclosure and winder for a superlight, base loaded vertical antenna, mainly for SOTA operating. The antenna is ideal for use with a 6m fiber-glass or carbon-fiber mast.

It is a redesign of the approach of an antenna marketed by QRPguys and developed by Joe Everhart, N2CX: http://qrpguys.com/qrpguys-tri-band-portable-vertical-antenna.

My approach differs in the following ways from the original one:

  1. I use one tapped coil on a singleT68-2 core instead of two coil in order to obtain the required inductances for 40 and 30 m (more details below).
  2. Instead of two SPST slide switches, I use a single SPDT 3-pole on-off-on switch.
  3. I added a common mode choke in order to reduce the effect of unavoidable asymmetries between the radiator and the counterpoise.
  4. Instead of four 10 ft. ground radials, my design can also be used with
    a) one elevated, resonant radial, tuned for each band by winding up the remaining wire, or
    b) three elevated, resonant radials attached to each other.

Materials

1 Amidon T68-2 toroid
1 Amidon / FairRite FT50-43 toroid
1 SPDT Switch On-Off-On, e.g. MIYAMA MS-167 (Reichelt: MS 167)
Two pieces of 0.5 mm magnet wire, 100 cm and ca. 55 cm
ca. 20m of SOTA beams antenna wire (diameter ca. 0.5 mm, https://www.sotabeams.co.uk/antenna-wire-lightweight-100m/)
1 SOTAbeams Mini Wire Winder (https://www.sotabeams.co.uk/mini-wire-winders/)
1 2mm plug Hirschmann 930308100 (Reichelt: MBI 1 SW)
1 gold-plated 2 mm connector (like those available for RC batteries, cf. ebay)
1 BNC connector for RG 174
1.6 m of RG 174
Various rubber cable grommets 3.4 - 5 mm inner diameter

Optional for sloped configuration from carbon-fiber masts:
1.8 m of polyester cord, e.g. SOTAbeams hi-viz antenna cord, https://www.sotabeams.co.uk/hi-viz-antenna-cord/
1 aluminium peg, like https://www.sotabeams.co.uk/aluminium-alloy-peg-price-per-one-peg/
Heat-shrink tube

Assembly

  1. Cut the radiator to length; I recommend starting with 5.17 m plus 10 - 15 cm extra for tuning.
  2. Prepare the common-mode choke: Twist 55 cm of 0.5. magnet wire tightly in order to obtain a 50 ohms impedance and wind 11 turns through the FT50-43 toroid.
  3. Mount the BNC connector to the RG 174 cable and put it throuth the two 3 mm holes on the left legt of the enclosure as a strain relief (see picture).
  4. Solder connect the other end of the RG 174 to the two ends of the common mode choke. At this point, polarity does not yet matter.
  5. Use a continuity tester or ohmmeter to figure out which of the two open ends of the common-mode choke are connected to the ground shield of the RG 174. Mark that, e.g. with a black permanent pen.
  6. Mount the black 2mm plug and the SPDT switch and solder the magnet wire marked in step 5 to this plug.
  7. Put the end of the radiator wire through the 1.2 mm holes on the opposite leg of the enclosure (see picture).
  8. Prepare the loading coil: Take the 100 cm of 0.5. magnet wire and wind 25..26 turns, then add a short tap, then another 20..21 turns. Leave at least 10 cm on either end so that you can adjust the tap by adding a turn on one side and removing one on the other.
  9. Now tune the loading coil with a component tester or other device for measuring inductances. The total coil should have 11.5 - 12 uH, the 25..26 turns should have 3.4 - 3.6 uH. It is important to shorten the rest of the coil (i.e. the 20..21 turns) while measuring the inductance of the lower 25..26 turns.
  10. Now connect
    a) the open end of the common-mode choke with the start of the loading coil
    b) the tap of the loading coil with the left (or right) connector of the SPDT switch,
    c) the end of the loading coil and the radiator wire with the middle connector of the SPDT switch, and
    d) the start of the loading coil with the remaining connector of the SPDT switch.

You are all set, except for the radials / counterpoise. I recommend a single, resonant counterpoise, which gives greater efficiency but is a bit more difficult to tune. Solder the 2mm plug to one end and secure it with 3.2 mm heat-shrink tube. Tie the other end to the mini-winder in order to not loose it when throwing out the counterpoise from a mountain top. Wind up all wire.

The rubber cable grommets are attached to the end of the radiator wire and allow a flexible connection of the wire to the mast; this idea is from Heinz Baertschi, HB9BCB.

Tuning

  1. Put the SPDT switch into the position in which it shortens the entire loading coil.
  2. Attach the antenna to a 6m mast with an initial radiator length of 5.17 m. Fold back the extra radiator wire.
  3. The enclosure/winder should be attached to the mast with two rubber bands, which will go cross-wise from the four legs of the winder. The enclouse should be ca. 75 - 80 cm above ground level.
  4. Now tune the antenna to resonance by winding up the counterpoise. A good starting point is ca. 5 m. Make sure that the counterpoise is sloping down from the enclosure. In particular the first meters should not touch the ground. The height above ground of the end influences the tuning. Elevating the end ca. 60 cm gives better performance, but can be difficult in the field.
  5. Mark the tuned length of the counterpoise, ideally with something you can feel in bad light, e.g. a knot of cord or rubbert band etc.
  6. Now tune for 30 and 40 m accordingly.
    You are all set!

When using with a carbon-fiber mast, the tuning may change, and it may be unstable if the wind changes the distance between mast and radiator. In this case, I recommend a steeply sloped configuration, i.e. holding the winder/enclosure ca. 1m away from the base of the mast. For this purpose, tie the hi-viz cord to the two unused holes in the enclosure, add a loop to the other end, and fix it with a peg. The antenna may require retuning for this configuration.

Acknowledgments

The antenna is inspired by the original design by Joe Everhart, N2CX. The idea to use a single SPDT on-off-on switch and the use of rubber cable grommets is from Heinz Baertschi, HB9BCB. The tiny common-mode choke is inspired by the "pico balun" from Richard Newstead, G3CWI, available via SOTAbeams (https://www.sotabeams.co.uk/pico-balun-1-1-or-4-1-balun-kit/).

remixed_from.title: Dual Blower/Radial Fan Duct Mount (Tevo Tarantula)

description.text:
The Absolute BEST dual fan duct!

Now capable of 200 mm bridging!!
Both fans are pressure fitted, just snap them on and they are good to go.
The air current is directed straight onto the tip of the nozzle, hardening the plastic as soon as it leaves the nozzle, while maintaining the hot end temperature!

This is a remix of several great designs, of which I took the best and polished to near perfection.

  • The model is to be printed upside down (the air canals should be at the top) with supports.
  • Some hot ends are really close to the heat block, and some height adjustment may be needed

description.text:
My Giant Lego figure lamp!

It's 48.5cm talls. About 12 times the size of an original Lego figure. This is a redesign/blow-up of the Blank Minifig, Jumbo Snap-Together Version design by Skimbal.

Modifications:

  • made the head hollow to fit a lamp (e14 fitting)
  • modified the chest to be firmer and fit a lamp
  • added wedges for firmer stand
  • added tube to the hips for wiring

I only added the modified files. The original files can be found in the originial project by Skimbal. Just print them 3x larges as provided.

Notes on the chest:
Only after my print I modified the chest for what I think should a) offer a better fit to the hips and b) added - for your convenience - a hole for the fitting. I had to make this space afterwards, which looks a bit messy if you take of the head. The modified chest doesn't have a hole for the wire. You can easily drill this hole in afterwards. I think if you add a hole to the design, you should print with support. Without the hole you can print without support and save some time and material.

Notes on the wedges:
Also I added two wedges to put in the hips after the legs are attached. This will make the figure stand a bit more firm.

title: Raspberry Pi Mount for Mediasonic Enclosure

description.text:
Mounting bracket for attaching a Raspberry Pi 3 to a Mediasonic 8 bay disk enclosure.

I've been using a Raspberry Pi 3 running Open Media Vault with one of my Mediasonic disk enclosures. This enclosure happens to be the 8 bay, ProRaid (H8R2-SU3S2). I wanted a way to mount the Pi to the enclosure, but place it in the airflow from the fans to also keep it cool.

This mount should also work on the non-RAID version of the enclosure.

The mount uses the original hardware that the fans use to attach them to the enclosure (there's just enough length on the screws), and it uses two button head screws for the Pi case. My Pi is in a VILROS case, but I suspect other cases could be used as well.

Using this mount allows the Pi to be neatly attached to the enclosure, keeps it cool, allows the use of a short USB 3 cable, and still provides access to all of the Pi's IO ports.

I printed this in PETG, but any filament should work.

Having the problem of teaching digital electronics to a blind student, we designed a haptic 4x4 Karnaugh map in a FreeCAD file to be printed in a witbox BQ 3D printer.
It consists of a simple matrix with holes and cylinders. Each cylinder stands for a '1' or 'X' bit as input in the Karnaugh map. Each square in the matrix has got a hole to insert a cylinder, in case of having a '1' or a 'X' in that box. The column and row headings (Gray code) are in Braille. The final result is the base and the 32 cylinders, 16 of '1' and 16 of 'X'. The whole set can be carried in a small plastic bag (15x15 cm).

title: DIY - ARDUINO BASED CAR PARKING ASSISTANT

description.text:
Introduction

Hi Friends,

I am back again with another Arduino based home automation project. This time I am trying to make my partner's life easy by installing a collision avoidance system in the garage to help her park the car safely without hitting the garage wall.

So, in this video, I am going to use an ultrasonic sensor to calculate the car's distance from the garage wall and display it using green, yellow and red LEDs. The color of LEDs indicates whether to keep moving, slow down, stop or go back.

The total cost of the project is around $20 - $25.

Step 1: Logic

The project has 3 phases

Phase 1: Waiting for the car In this phase the device keeps looking for a moving object within the sensors proximity. If an object enters the proximity then one of the three LEDs turns on based on how far the moving object is. If the object is way too close, then a noise is made to make the moving object aware of the distance.

Phase 2: No car in the garage If there is no object in the proximity then turn off all the LEDs.

Phase 3: The car has stopped moving (Parked in the right spot) If the object has stopped moving and is still in the proximity wait for 20 CPU cycles and then turn off the LEDs.

Step 2: Hardware Requirement

For this very simple project we need:

  • A Perfboard
  • An Arduino nano/uno (whatever is handy)
  • A Red, Green and a Yellow LED (Light Emitting Diode)
  • 3 x 220ohm resistor for the LEDs
  • One HC-SRO4 Ultrasonic Sensor
  • A Buzzer shield or A buzzer and a 100 ohm resistor
  • A 220v AC to 5v DC Buck step-down module
  • One Female Pin Header Strip
  • An Ethernet cable
  • Some connecting cables
  • A USB cable to upload the code to the Arduino
  • and general soldering equipments

Step 3: Assembly

Let start by connecting the LEDs to the board.

Connect the Red LED to pin D2, Yellow LED to D3 and the Green LED to D4 of the Arduino by putting in a 220ohm resistor between the Arduino board and the LEDs. Now lets connect the Buzzer to analogue pin A0. Next, connect the Trig pin of the Ultrasonic Sensor to D5 and the Echo pin to D6 of the Arduino. Once all the modules are connected to the Arduino board, its time for us to connect all the positive and negative pins together. Connect all the positive pins of the modules to the +5v supplied by the Buck Step-Down Module and the negative pins to the -ve terminal of the Module. That's it, we can now upload our sketch to the board.

In this assembly I am using 3 LEDs to display the distance, however you can replace the 3 LEDs with a RGB LED, or you can also use an array of LEDs like an audio level indicator to display the movement of the car.

Step 4: My Setup

OK now lets see what I have made.

I have installed the Arduino, buzzer, the ultrasonic sensor and the three 220 ohms resistors on one Perfboard. The 3 LEDs and the power module is installed on a second Perfboard. I will be covering the LEDs with a translucent cover to give it a nice look.

The 220v power supply will be connected to the screw terminal block. The base unit will then be connected to the LEDs and the power supply with an Ethernet cable.

Step 5: The Code

int trigPin = PD5; // Sensor Trip pin connected to Arduino pin D5
int echoPin = PD6; // Sensor Echo pin connected to Arduino pin D6
int redLED = PD2; // Red LED connected to pin D2
int yellowLED = PD3; // Yellow LED connected to pin D3
int greenLED = PD4; // Green LED connected to pin D4
int buzzer = A0; // Buzzer connected to Analogue pin A0
long TempDistance = 0; // A variable to store the temporary distance
int counter = 0; // Counter value to check if the object has stopped moving

void setup() {

  Serial.begin(9600);
  pinMode(trigPin, OUTPUT);
  pinMode(echoPin, INPUT);
  pinMode(redLED, OUTPUT);
  pinMode(greenLED, OUTPUT);
  pinMode(yellowLED, OUTPUT);
  pinMode(buzzer, OUTPUT);

}

void loop() {

  long duration, Distance;
  digitalWrite(trigPin, LOW);
  delayMicroseconds(2);
  digitalWrite(trigPin, HIGH);
  delayMicroseconds(10);
  digitalWrite(trigPin, LOW);
  duration = pulseIn(echoPin, HIGH);
  Distance = (duration/2) / 74; // Distance in Inches

  if(counter < 20){ // Do the rest if the car is still moving
    if (Distance > 200) { // Nothing in the garrage
      turnThemAllOff();
    }
    if ((Distance > 55) && (Distance <= 200)) { // Turn on Green LED
      digitalWrite(greenLED, HIGH);
      digitalWrite(yellowLED, LOW);
      digitalWrite(redLED, LOW);
      noTone(buzzer);
   }
   if ((Distance > 15) && (Distance <= 55)) { // Turn on Yellow LED
      digitalWrite(yellowLED, HIGH);
      digitalWrite(redLED, LOW);
      digitalWrite(greenLED,LOW);
      noTone(buzzer);
   }
   if (Distance <= 15) { // Turn on Red LED
      digitalWrite(redLED, HIGH);
      digitalWrite(greenLED,LOW);
      digitalWrite(yellowLED, LOW);
      noTone(buzzer);
   }
   if (Distance < 8) { // Item is way to close - start the buzzer
      tone(buzzer, 500);
   }

  }

  if ((Distance == TempDistance) || ((Distance+1) == TempDistance) || ((Distance-1) == TempDistance)){
      if(counter >= 20){ // Turn off the lights if the object hasn't moved for 20 cycles (no change in distance)
       Serial.println("No movement detected, turning off the lights");
       turnThemAllOff();
      } else {
       counter++;
      }
  } else {
  counter = 0; // Reset counter if there is a movement
  }
  TempDistance = Distance;

  Serial.print(Distance);
  Serial.println(" inches");
  Serial.print("Counter : ");
  Serial.println(counter); delay(500); 
}

// Function to turn the LEDs off
void turnThemAllOff(){
  digitalWrite(redLED, LOW);
  digitalWrite(greenLED,LOW);
  digitalWrite(yellowLED, LOW);
  noTone(buzzer);
}

Start the code by defining the constants and the global variables that will be used throughout the code.

Then define the pin modes in the setup section of the code.

Then create a function to turn off all the LEDs and the buzzer.

Now, calculate the "Distance" in inches by reading the values received from the Ultrasonic Sensor.

Then by checking the value of the "Distance" we will turn on and off the LEDs based on how far the object is. If the distance is greater than 200 then turn off all the LEDs and the buzzer as the object is out of range. Else if it is between 55 and 200 then turn on the green LED. If the object is between 15 and 55 then turn on the yellow LED, and if the object goes closer than 15 inches then turn on the red LED until it reaches 8 inches. When the distance becomes less than 8 start the buzzer along with the red LED.

Next bit of the code is to set the value of the counter based on the cars movement which then decides when to turn off the LEDs. It compares the value of "Distance" with the "TempDistance" and if the values are same (object hasn't moved) then increments the counter. If the object moves any-time during this process the counter is reset to 0. Finally the "TempDistance" is set to the value of "Distance".

Just before comparing the Distances we also need to check if the counter value has exceed 20. I am doing this to stop the below code from executing if the car is in a steady position.

Lastly we just need to add a small delay to our sketch to pause the code for a while.

Step 6: Quick Demo

So this is how I have installed the unit in my garage.

As I walk close to the sensor the light changes from green to yellow to red and ultimately the buzzer goes on when I am too close to the sensor. In my case I have installed the buzzer next to the Arduino however I will recommend you to install the buzzer along with the LEDs. If you want you can also flash the red LED when the buzzer goes on.

So now, my partner can park the car easily without making any assumptions. Doesn't matter how many times she fail her driving test she is not going to break my wall (even when she is drunk). Not that I am asking her to drive when she is drunk (just kidding).

Thanks again for watching this video! I hope it helps you. If you want to support me, you can subscribe to my channel and watch my other videos. Thanks, ca again in my next video.

<iframe allowfullscreen="None" frameborder="0" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/LQGhprwuHe0" ></iframe>

So, in this video, I am going to use an ultrasonic sensor to calculate the car's distance from the garage wall and display it using green, yellow and red LEDs. The color of LEDs indicates whether to keep moving, slow down, stop or go back.

Openbuilds Powerpack Giveaway - Please Vote

This project is a finalist of the Openbuilds Powerpack Giveaway.

  • Vote for the best project here :)
  • View finalists here


Prusa i3 Bear Upgrade V2.0

Introduction

This is an aluminum frame conversion for the Prusa i3 MK2, MK2s, MK2.5 and MK3.

Josef PRŮŠA has created numerous of incredible 3D printers and its latest Prusa i3 MK3 is capable of very impressive print quality for a very low price. A huge thanks to him and all its team!

One of the down point of the Prusa i3 MK2 and MK3 is the rigidity of the frame. A very good project has solved those problems by using 3030 extrusion aluminum : Prusa 3030 Haribo Edition. So why another conversion build? Check the next section ;)

Why another conversion build?

Here are the features that explain why I decided to create another printer upgrade.

  • Use as much as possible original parts (no need to print a new RAMBo cover nor change any cable, rods or firmware)
  • Compatible with MK2, MK2s MK2.5 and MK3
  • Let user choose between two versions :
    • Half upgrade : similar to MK3 and cheaper
    • Full upgrade : stronger but more expensive
  • Highly detailed manual
  • Use more aluminum and less printed parts (3D printed parts can crack and are less reliable)
  • Use Openbuilds hardware :
    • Single platform of multitude compatible hardware parts (extrusion, plates, low profile screws...)
    • V-Slot offers more possibilities for printed parts and customisation than T-Slot
    • Open source with powerful community
    • Easy to square and build
    • Worldwide shipping plus several other shops selling these parts
  • Other type of aluminum extrusions can be supported thanks to parametric design (check Fusion 360 files)
  • 3D printed parts designed using advanced techniques like selective infill, clean vertical holes, sharp angle...
  • Open source by providing STL, STEP and Autodesk Fusion 360 files

Full And Half upgrades

The Prusa i3 Bear upgrade is proposed in two versions: full or half upgrade.

  • Half upgrade : upgrade your MK2/MK2s/MK2.5 frame to MK3 type
  • Full upgrade : has a redesigned and stronger Z axis for all MK2 and MK3 printers but is more expensive

Here is a comparison table to help you choose :

  Half Upgrade   Full Upgrade
Compatibility   MK2(s) and MK2.5   MK2(s), MK2.5 and MK3
Y axis rigidity   ♥ ♥ ♥ ♥ ♥   ♥ ♥ ♥ ♥ ♥
Z axis rigidity   ♥ ♥ ♥   ♥ ♥ ♥ ♥ ♥
Noise level   ♥ ♥ ♥ ♥   ♥ ♥ ♥ ♥
Customisation   ♥ ♥ ♥   ♥ ♥ ♥ ♥ ♥
Material cost   $   $ $
Number of V-Slots to cut   6 (4 different lengths)   7 (4 different lengths)
Number of V-Slots to tap   4   0
Can I place the printer inside an
enclosure and PSU outside?		 No, PSU rigidify the Z frame   Yes
Capability to increase Z axis height?
(need customisation)		   No   Yes


Half upgrade use the same v-slots and printed part for MK2(s) and MK2.5. However, the full upgrade has 3 different versions, one for MK2(s), one for MK2.5 and another one for MK3.

Several printed parts are shared between all these versions. This makes easier to move from half to full upgrade, or full upgrade MK2 to full upgrade MK3.

Go to HALF upgrade page or FULL upgrade page (on my GitHub).

Community And Support

The official repository of this project is on my GitHub : github.com/gregsaun.

The best way to talk about this upgrade is to join the OpenBuilds thread. Be careful when you join OpenBuilds, you will be soon tempted by building a CNC or a Laser machine!

You can also open an issue on GitHub if you prefer or add a comment here.

Manual, Drawings, BOM, Sources

Everything is available on my GitHub : github.com/gregsaun.

Changelog

2018.02.28 : MK3 Full Upgrade only : fix export issue with y_motor_mount and y_idler (was not the latest version)
2018.03.10 : All Full Upgrade : fix issue in manual where step 4.1 was not possible due to missing t-nuts

Feedbacks from users

Some feedbacks from users that built the half upgrade v1 :

"I'm really happy. It's really great.It works really fine. It's a professional update. I was searching for a mk3 prusa frame update and I find this"

"Excellent with instructions, this was like buying a Prusa kit all over again, only better"

"Your frame idea made the machine a lot sturdier"

"It seems printing noise has reduced significantly after upgrade"

"Amazing work on the detail and on the machine"

"That frames makes it into totally different beast!"

"It's a professional well made update. And the manual it's really easy to follow"

"Very detailed work, are you sure you dont want to take on the role of the new Josef Prusa ?? I mean the designs are just amazing"

Huge THANKS to all of you! ♥

Current status

Half Upgrade : Finished

Full Upgrade MK2(s) : Finished

Full Upgrade MK2.5 : MK2.5 upgrade kits have not been shipped from Prusa factory yet. The only differences for this upgrade will be the RAMBo cover mounts. All parts, documentation and tests are finished.

Full Upgrade MK3 : No build as been tried as I do not own a MK3. However, all parts, documentation and tests are finished. Waiting feedback from first builders (big thank you for the help!).

Thank you

Thank you for all people helping me on this project.

Thank you Openbuilds for your hardware and community.

Special thanks to DoItWithSmile (jay3D), kabar03 and xequtor for actively helping me and for their feedbacks.

Links

  • Help me continue this work by supporting me via my Patreon. (I have tons of new idea)
  • GitHub Project Page
  • Openbuilds forum page
  • Openbuilds build page
  • My Thingiverse

Sources

Here are a list of sources I used to build this project :

  • Prusa : http://www.prusa3d.com
  • Prusa 3030 Haribo Edition : https://github.com/PrusaMK2Users/3030_Haribo_Edition
  • Openbuilds : https://www.openbuilds.org
  • Prusa i3 Solidworks parts from jzkmath : https://github.com/jzkmath/Original-Prusa-i3/

Huge thanks to these projects, without them this project can not exist!

description.text:
The daruma is more than an amulet, it is a representation of that goal that we have imposed and a reminder, a motivation, so that our forces do not fail us during the process.

Normally the Japanese give daruma dolls to offer the opportunity to someone to achieve a purpose, for example on his birthday, New Year or a new project, but naturally we can also give it away at any time we want, because always We have goals and purposes that we would like to make.

When we have decided our purpose, we must paint one of his eyes and work hard to achieve it. And when we get our purpose, we should paint the other eye as a sign of gratitude.

Legend has it that monk Bodhidharma (founder of Zen Buddhism) did not attain enlightenment until 9 years after meditating alone in a cave. And after so long without moving, not only did his arms and legs fall from atrophy, but the monk himself tore off his eyelids to concentrate better and avoid falling asleep.

Having these legends in mind, it is easy to understand why daruma has that shape, but it is also interesting to emphasize that all the design of the doll, its shape, its color, its white eye cavities and its beautiful face, has a special symbolism.

Another feature of daruma dolls is facial hair. The eyebrows are shaped like a crane while the hair on the cheeks resembles a turtle shell. Both animals are symbols of longevity in Japan, so the facial beauty symbolizes longevity when it comes to achieving our goal.

description.text:
All oil furnaces or burners used in heating a house have a pair of electrodes that use a spark to ignite the fuel. The spacing of these electrodes is very specific to produce optimum results, but most electrodes in the market require the same settings.

I created this thing based on a product I found on the internet which allows you to set the spacing very quickly and accurately without messing about with tape measures or calipers or other measuring devices.

The specs to which this has been set up (and which should be the same for most furnaces but obviously check your specific model needs!) are:

  1. Distance between electrodes = 1/8"
  2. Distance of electrodes forward of nozzle = 1/8"
  3. Distance of "height" above the center of the nozzle = 1/2"

Once you print it you just slide it in the beck and align the two electrodes with the two "seats" created by the tool. If you do an image search for "Oil Burner Electrode Gauge" you will find pictures of a similar tool in use.

title: Base Stand for Gothic Lantern to add a Push-Light

description.text:
This is a stable base I created for the Gothic Lantern (by Shira). The base has a 70mm recess hole in which to accommodate a basic LED cupboard push-light (as shown).
The base is 30mm deep in order for the push-light to fit up inside sufficiently to not get scratched by the surface the lamp is stood on.

The base was printed independently and in my case, was glued on with superglue. Those more proficient may be able to incorporate it directly into the original lamp file, but note that Shira does not allow derivatives of the original lamp.

The circular disc with the hole is what I used inside the lamp to attach the LED flame bulb that I had converted to run from mains power to 4xAA batteries. The outer circle sits snugly within the lamp and at 1mm is flexible enough to wedge into place (being held by the lamp glass/upright bits), with the batteries hidden below it and the bulb glued into the center hole. - Hopefully the attached images will help that make some kind of sense?

The photos show the lamp, base and LED light, all painted using the dry-brush technique (Black base with gold highlights)

description.text: This micro dot dispenser delivers 50 micro liters per button push. It was designed for the application of discrete known volumes of cyanoacrylate (CA) glue during medical device manufacture.

Introduction

To ensure repeatable results during manufacture, we needed a dispenser that would deliver the same small quantity of glue each time. Although many commercial options do exist, they are often expensive and rely on pressurized air for actuation. I wanted to design a small hand held dispenser with a simple mechanism that could interface with a standard 2 ml syringe.

How I Designed this

First I used my calipers get the critical syringe dimensions and made a basic model, I knew that I wanted to interface with the finger tabs on the back of the syringe body so I made sure to get that profile exact.

Then I designed the plunger rail and an actuator rail to match, I made sure to space them in such a way that there would be sufficient room for the housing.

Next I sketched a profile for the housing and extruded it along the length of the syringe body.

Next I capped off the front of the housing and added an extra groove for the actuator rail. Also added two extrudes at the back and cut a slot in each, these guide the actuator rail during actuation.

I then made a cut out at the back of the housing to match the profile of the finger tabs on the syringe. I added two small circular extrudes to hold the syringe in place once it had been pushed into the housing. I added some chamfers for ease of use and some fillets for aesthetics.

I made some changes to the actuator rack, including a cylindrical extrude at the front which I used to center the spring, and a beam to attach the push button to.

A cross section of the final assembly is shown below. When assembling the dispenser, first drop a 4 mm OD spring into the housing, there are cylindrical extrudes on both the housing and the actuator rail which fit into the center of the spring (I used one from an old pen). Then the actuator rail (red) can be slid in from the back until the tabs at the back click into the slots of the housing. Finally the push button can be pushed onto the the actuator rail. After that, just insert the syringe and make sure the plunger mates with the plunger rail.

Notes

I was really happy with how this dispenser turned out, the fits and tolerances worked perfectly, and the over all feel was great. There were some issues with dispensing though, and I would include a ratchet on version 2 to prevent the piston from pushing back, also the CA I was using was not very viscous so there was a small amount of leakage after each application. The next iteration should also include some kind of draw back mechanism, i'e two steps forward one step back, this would hopefully produce a nice clean drop with no leakage afterwards.

Printing Settings

For these parts I used formlabs Grey Resin V3, it has a great surface finish and I've found the dimensional accuracy to be pretty high. I used 0.6 mm support points with a density setting of 1. There were some internal supports on the housing but they were easy to remove and I filed the inside with a round file before curing.

description.text:
A simple quick release GoPro compatible adapter/mount for the Mobius 2 camera. Just slide the camera in to the enclosure. To remove, just push down on the tab and push the camera out.

It has a cut out on the side so you can access the buttons.

I wanted something that would allow me to quickly remove the camera whilst providing a strong and sturdy hold. The enclosure has a small gap between its walls and the camera causing a rattle, so the sturdy part needs some work, but it is fully functional.

You must not print this on its back or front. I recommend printing side on for maximum strength. If you print on the back or front the layers will snap instead of flexing like it's designed to. If you print upright or up-side-down you risk breaking the case on the thinner parts on removal of the supports. Printing side on will result in the print being strongest where it needs to be.

description.text:
These are mounting brackets for a BeagleBone Black (BBB) and two 40mm fans.

They are designed to be mounted horizontally inside a delta printer bottom triangle underneath the build bed, but surely possible to use other mounting configurations. Furthermore for mounting to work as designed, there needs to be two horizontal 2020 profiles with 20mm gap between them for the BBB ethernet and power connectors to remain accessible. Originally a Replicape has been thought to be installed as a cape on top of the BBB, but the BBB bracket works with or without any cape, however, the fan bracket might not fit with higher capes. The fan bracket was designed so that the fans are installed blowing air away (upwards) from the BBB/cape, but the fans can be installed also the other way around.

title: High Hat - Somewhere to Hang Your Hat

description.text:
I like to wear hats, but living in a studio, storage space is limited. Some people use shelves and hanging closet organizers, which are bulky, or hooks, which hide the beautiful designs on your hat. My wife asked if there were some way that I could design a thing that held hats and presented them cleanly since there are so many people who spend big money on their clothing, especially the streetwear crowd. So I designed the High Hat.

Customize your High Hat by swapping out colours to match your hats! Laid on its side, the model is 50 mm high, so you can easily stripe it by switching filament. The window is 20 mm, so it's split into sections with 15 mm, 20 mm, and 15 mm. See Print Settings for more details.

Use a 3M Command Strip (small) and attach it to the back. If you're using it near walls or other High Hats, leave at least 150 mm (~6 inches) on all sides for a roomy fit.

The current design matches my hat size, which is around 7 3/8". For people with smaller hats, you'll need to scale it down for now while I come up with an appropriate small version of the High Hat. Here's a resource for how to measure your hat size.

There is a small window at the back so you can check if your hat is sitting flat. It also provides an easy way to remove the Command Strip.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

i3 MK3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.3 mm

Infill:

25%

Notes:

Recommend printing in PETG and ABS and at least 25% infill, where you get better balance of strength and flexibility. The hook does bounce a little when you hang your hat, and PLA will audibly crack when you put too much force on it.

The MK3 print bed is quite large, so if it's too big for your bed, rotating it by 45 degrees can make it fit a 200x200 bed without scaling.

To switch out colours on your print, the following commands may not necessarily work with your printer, so make sure you understand what it's doing before simply plugging it in. Using Simplify3D, enter this command into the Process Settings under the Scripts tab to enable changing of filaments (source):

{REPLACE "\n; layer 19, Z = " "; layer 19\nG28 Y0 X0\nM300\nM25\nG92 E0\nG28 Y0 X0\n; layer 19 "}

The extruder will pause the print, move to the point (0,0), then once you switch out the filament and hit continue, it will resume the print.

If you're using 0.3 mm layer height and you want to split the colours 15mm/20mm/15mm, the layer number you'll replace in the command should be around layer 51 and layer 118.

title: Card Reader Housing for Hama 35 in 1 USB2.0

description.text:
An old USB 2.0 card reader was around for some time. If you usually use laptop PC, no problem but when it comes to desktop PCs, it is always pain in the neck to find out a suitable cable -if it is not dangling out-, attach it to PC, find a place on the desk etc etc. You may have your PC has already an installed card readers on itself but finding that tiny slots suitable for your card type under desk where mostly PCs are located is a bit hassle. It is best to keep it near your desktop, where it is easy to see its slots, readily attached to PC and on all the time while PC is running. I can not think of a place better than just under the desk surface, near your hands and eyes. Therefore I have designed this "thing" to place the card reader under my desk. The reader snaps in housing with a click and stays there. When you attach it to its place, housing squeezes further the reader and keep it in its place firmly. If you have the same kind of Hama card reader and mostly don't know where to put it, then, this THING is for you..
Best wishes...

title: Prusa MK3 Adjustable Y belt Tensioner

description.text: An adjustable tension-er for the y-belt. The oem setup of using the idler support attachment bolts to do tensioning let the belt wander a lot and it usually ended up bearing pretty hard against one side or the other of the pulley. I thought that it would be more stable if I could tighten up the mounting bolts to align the support. This necessitated a scheme to allow tension adjustment. I came up with this. It requires a pivot pin. I used a piece of 2mm carbon rod I had laying around. Piano wire (2mm or 3/32") would be a good substitute. The thru holes for the pivot pin are @ 2mm in the .stl files. so there is room to drill them out to a reasonable size. I sized the holes in the bracket part to be a light press on the pin and opened the hole in the hinge part to move freely (~0.05-0.1mm ~ 0.002 - 0.004" larger than the pin). The tension bolt is a 3mm 16 - 18mm long. Can be longer. This iteration uses the stock thru bolt and pulley so use the same caution not to over-tighten the thru bolt when you assemble it. There are two versions. One with the pulley located at the oem height in z and a lowered (1.25mm) design that uses RHDreamboxes y belt holder that levels the belt path.. The retainer nuts should be installed before you press the hinge pin in. I am using a detail on the design that uses aluminum spacers as crush tubes to allow the thru bolt to be tightened up against the center bearing race to locate the bearing at the c/l of the bracket. I'll put that up if there is interest. It requires well made tubes. I used a 3mm drill to clean out the slot on the tension bolt support and a flat washer under the head of the bolt. The support to bolt head surface is cylindrical to compensate for tension bolt angularity.

title: Z Axis Extension For Wanhao i3 Plus only (REV.1)

description.text:
UPDATE: Realized that I had forgotten to add the file for the Universal Filament guide I designed, it is now included.

This is my first prototype for a Z Axis extension kit for the Wanhao Duplicator i3 Plus. All the other Z axis extensions on Thingiverse do not work on the plus model due to the guide rods being mounted differently than the other i3 models, this kit works specifically with the i3 plus, and is sized as such to also not interfere with the different wanhao z brace kits that can be printed.

This file includes one bracket file that needs printed twice, one of them mirrored from the other, as well as a custom filament guide that can be either glued or 3M adhesive'd to the cross member, it can be used with or without the stock spool holder, but I advise using an external as the weight on top of the gantry causes more vibration during printing. The brackets contain a 10mm hole on the side for hanging accessories to be added, there are two separate styles that are included here, but anything you design with a 10mm pin can be installed for your specific tools.

For installation you need 12 (3x12-15mmm) screws to replace the stock cross member screws, as well as 4 (3x50mm) screws to go down through the guide rod block to the guide rod seat, If you are only installing the extension you will need 4 3mm nylock nuts, if you are installing or have installed the z brace kit, you will need an extra 8 (12 total). You will also want a fair number of 3mm washers, how many depends on the thickness you get, to go between the bracket and the cross member, as it was originally designed to fit inside the gantry towers, and thus is slightly smaller.

It is important to install the Guide Rod blocks first, and then set the free gantry down onto the guide rods, and then install the brackets to ensure no issues with seating the rods.

Use 0.75 mm² (1 mm diameter) Copper Rods for 2.4-GHz-Antenna-Extension:

Position - Length:
A - 60 mm
B - 53 mm
C - 52 mm
D - 51.5 mm
E - 51 mm
F - 50 mm

If you want to use 1.5 mm² (1.4 mmm diameter) Copper Rods, shorten the length of the rods around 1 mm.

To use 2.5 mm² (2 mmm diameter) Copper Rods, drill bigger holes and shorten the length of the rods around 2 mm.

Just center the rods in the holes and fixate them with glue.

Place the complete antenna-extension on your accesspoint-antenna and you have a directional WIFI Signal :)

The gain should be around 10 (+/- 2) dBi.

Have fun :)

description.text: E-cigarette Model
bracelet styles

This thing display the evolution of your heart rate along the time.
If you are stressed it's likely you'll get a curve with sharp edges like in second picture.
But from one second to the other, if you concentrate mind on your breathing or start meditation, or try to avoid thinking with words and pictures, it's likely the curve will become far softer, nearly sinusoïdal, like in first picture.
It's likely that you'll get a greater amplitude if you breathe deeply.
This is connected to cardiac coherence ( french "Cohérence cardiaque" https://www.coherenceinfo.com/ ), mindfulness meditation ( french "méditation de la pleine conscience"), and ... humm... in my humble opinion, to Holy Spirit (pneuma, breath in the Bible)

If you work with scad files, you'll need to download the pcb enclosure library - 3 ( thing https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2808537 ) and the 4duino enclosure library ( https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2808559 )

The main board is a 4duino: https://www.4duino.com/

And I used this heart rate sensor from SeeedStudio :
https://www.seeedstudio.com/Grove-Ear-clip-Heart-Rate-Sensor-p-1116.html

You can find the source code for the 4duino at

title: Sticky’s Creality CR-10S CR10 frame brace stiffener – no loss of Z height!
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Printed some other multi-purpose mounts for this and they simply didn’t fit. The angle was wrong for the threaded rod and the nuts were fastening at an angle and the 4mm fasteners were too weedy…

…so I designed a new one.

There are no stupid printed plastic fasteners with this kit. Why would you print when metal ones are cheap and better?

The brace is only to stop vibration. Do not overtighten or it will pull your frame out of whack and you’ll get bed levelling grief.

It may fit other Creality and Hictop models but I haven’t tested. If it fits your printer then please leave a positive comment.

I've tested this and it does not limit movement in any direction.

Enjoy…

You need:

4x prints of this file
8x M5 cap head Allen screws (20mm).
8x M5 T-nuts
2x 68cm lengths of M8 threaded rod
8x M8 nuts (Nyloc optional)
8x 8mm flat washers

EDIT 2nd March 2018

Before fitting a frame brace, first consider whether or not you actually need one. The objective is to reduce vibration and improve the quality of very tall prints.

At the moment I'm trying to print small objects on a cold, snow-bound conservatory. When I turn the heating on the bed levelling changes massively. Why is that?

It's because the aluminium frame is now braced with a steel rod and the two have totally different thermal expansion characteristics. So much so that I'm going to remove the brace until the weather warms up at bit.

SMALL RANT: It seems to me that there's a lot of poorly conceived but pretty printer upgrades that people make but don't actually improve anything. Squash ball feet are a good example. These don't eliminate all vibration - they shift the resonant frequency - and on my old printer they made the prints much worse because the carriage was moving one way when the chassis was rebounding another. Think before you print before you build...

Give your Pi Zero 4 usb ports and a coaxial power connector.

• Pi Zero
  • USB3.0 Superspeed 4 Ports Hub
  • 2x M2.6*10 mm or shorter screws

The hub is usb 3.0 but the pi can only make use of it's usb 2.0 capabilities. I chose it because it has a power connector.

• Print the housing, with or without a hole for a pin header on the top
  • Remove the case from the usb hub
  • Desolder hub usb cable and cut away the top left part of the hub pcb, make sure to leave no shorts. Otherwise that part of the pcb is only occupied by the power led.
  • Cut away a little piece of the lower right part of the hub pcb, and a tab from that usb connectors shield.
  • Solder cables to the bottom of the hub pcb. Neither the original GND nor 5V pad should be used. Instead, desolder the little Q1 transistor and attach your 5V cable to the newly exposed pad, and attach the your ground cable to a usb connector shield.
  • Solder the other cable ends onto the pi. The angle of the cables are important for them to fit in the hole of the middle printed part in the next step.
  • Stick the usb hub through the middle printed part
  • Stick the hub in the bottom printed part
  • Screw it together
  • Snap the top on
Note

You can now power your pi through either the micro usb connector, or the power plug on the hub, but you should probably not plug in both at once, as they are connected together.

This new saw is very nice, but has a few issues with the attachments, print this and you will never experience the miter slipping again.

I put the graduations at 2.5 degrees and placed a mark at the important 22.5 degree spot.

you will need a 10-24 X 3/4" screw (I think its actually m5 x 1 pitch, but I can't get one of them), grind or file the head flush with the thread on opposite sides and press it through the knob.

You can press out the 5mm pin from the old miter (don't try to turn it, its knurled), drill the pin hole to 5mm in the new miter and press in the pin, use the original large knob and washers, I used a sharpie on the lettering.

I printed this with PLA and everything fits very well.

title: K3D Tevo Tornado modular cooling system

description.text:
K3D modular cooling system for Tevo Tornado

Video instruction: https://youtu.be/Bo5hwqo9qSM

Advantages:

  1. Modular design allows you to easily change the configuration when you want it
  2. Cooling modules are designed in such a way that the air flow is directed only to the zone requiring cooling.
  3. No screw, glue, or anything else is required for assembly
  4. All modules are interchangeable
  5. The rails can be printed horizontally
  6. If you design your module with the same rails, it will fit into the system
  7. If you design a base module with the same rail position relative to the extruder nozzle, then all modules will fit into it and will work.

K3D Modular cooling system was created to replace all the others. It gives unlimited possibilities for expansion due to a simple system for connecting modules. You can choose which part of the system to print and install on your printer, and if you do not like something, you can always fix it.

description.text: this is my dicey

I just made this on TinkerCAD and I know that it is bad, but I am just starting out with designing. Ask any questions! BTW I haven't actually printed this yet, as i am currently at school.

Orion Ross
Create cookie cutters using Inkscape/OpenSCAD!

I had issues using the cookie cutter creator from here http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:3433 when I'd create really complex files. It worked great for simple cookie cutters and is the inspiration for this script. His is far easier to use than this, but this will work on complex files and create a clean STL file as a result. While I could clean up the files produced by the original program using Blender/NetFabb, this process too a while. I also had issues where the resulting cookie cutter would only be one strand of filament thick which didn't cut cookies very well. This attempts to resolve all of those issues. Install Inkscape
Install Better Better DXF plugin (http://tim.cexx.org/?p=590)
Install OpenSCAD You need the Better Better DXF plugin since openSCAD supports only a certain type of DXF and Better Better supports layers which this scad script will need. In InkScape create a new document and draw your cookie cutter with the polygon tool (pencil)
On a new layer named "baseoutside" copy your base layer and scale your output up to something your hand can easily fit on. (I use 140%)
On a new layer named "baseinside" copy the base layer again and scale downward to get a thickness for the base (I use 75%)
On a new layer named "cutterinside" copy the base layer and scale this down just slight bit (%5)
On a new layer named "cutteroutside" copy the base layer and scale it up just a slight bit (%5) The script does a difference between your layers to find thickness of blade and the support. It then uses 2 parameters to set the height of each. The produced file should be a solid STL. Issues:
1) If things are not lining up when you load into openSCAD, delete that layer in inkscape, recreate it and save again. This seems to be a problem with the DXF export. I also had issues when I resized the document I would need to recreate each layer.
2) If layers are not appearing, make sure you are using Better Better DXF (it supports layers!)
3) I have a makerbot cupcake so my bed size is limited. I found that by setting the document size in Inkscape to 95x95 then keeping my largest layer of the cookie cutter inside of that would allow me to print the cutter and use the skirt feature of Slic3r without trouble. Notes on development:
Initial attempts were to do the scaling off one layer completely in openSCAD, the openSCAD DXF converter plugin lets you get dimensions which was useful but it would randomly place your imported file somewhere in the work area. When scaling it seemed to include the much larger area in the scale and this made alignment problematic. If you have a solution, let me know! I implemented this by using 4 sets of polygons that were generated by a script off the base polygon. I found this method much easier and it allowed me to produce cookie cutters with ease.

comments.text: You can draw them anyway you like. You will need to join the lines at the end into one line and then convert it to a path in Inkscape. remixed_from.title: Nerf Sledgefire Single Shot Shell - V2.0

description.text:
This shell allows you to fire Mega Darts from your Sledgefire by frontloading them. The advantage of this design is that you don't need to modify your (now expensive) blaster in any way for this to work. The disadvantage is that you can't preload darts into the shell. You have to put the shell in, then stick a dart on the front.

I have tested this design and the dart does not go nearly as far as the darts in the standard 3-shot shell. The dart fits snugly on the front cylinder and the shell fits perfectly in the blaster. I suspect the issue may be that air is escaping through the cracks between the layers. If someone else can solve this problem, I would be very grateful.
A simple redesign of a single-shot shell. Redesigned with Blender.

Notes:

I used ABS to print it, it runs well in my CZ 200 action after the post printing guide.

Note: Buy yourself a 5mm and 5.2mm drill bit and redrill all the holes, first with the 5mm before superglueing the parts and then with the 5.2mm after assembly.

Also slightly chamfer the pellet holes from the front with a large drill bit by hand or with something similar. This makes the cocking action a bit smoother.

Specifically use 19mm OD (outside diameter) O-rings, for instance 12x3.5mm, 13x3mm or 15x2mm. The space left for the O-ring is 3.5mm. 2mm O-rings are plentiful at motor spare shops, the others can be had at any industrial bearing company, for instance BMG. Insert the O-ring from the front, the hole is slightly bigger from that end.

This brick is inspired by the stock LEGO 6123809 brick.

Every island from The Legend of Zelda- The Wind Waker.
All 49 of them. Plus a generic ocean tile, and a sea platform thrown in for fun.
Some were made from ripped game data (Forest Haven, Outset island, Forbidden fortress, Windfall Island) some are duplicates with small changes (fairy isles, triangle isles, the eye reefs) and the rest are designed more or less from scratch.
They're not to scale, and some are more accurate than others, but they're all there, complete with their grid assignments and a reference chart.
Some details I intentionally left out, like trees and large stones, though some of the islands I pulled form game data had those built in already. I may go back and refine some of them, I'll try to document any updates I do.

It was a bit difficult for me to wrap my mind around imperial screw sizes of the original from chuckbobuck, so I removed every one of them.

Now you need super glue and some filament pieces for alignment. I also made 2 versions for the body - one for electric guitar pegs and one for the classic 1/4" (please correct me if I name them wrong). Print the neck as dense as possible, because it likes to bend over time and because of the weight.

Some parts are still needed from the original - except the big disc in the center on the bottom of the body.

you will also notice the "pillar" in the bodies. This is to prevent underextrusion after >200mm travels through the body. Cura and other slicers are too stupid to do small steps - they never see the "big picture". This pillar traps the slicer now to jump on the small 2D-Island of the piller to get back to normal extrusion and go then to the small island generated by the peg holes. Just remove the pillar when done - tadaa!

EDIT I had a marker bit in the std-peg version of the body. If you downloaded the files and did not read this, download again please. Sry.
