description.text: Me and my colleagues got nerved by the mess on our desks, so I decided to create a simple shelf that can be clipped on the iMac. There are some slots on the bottom of the mac for the sound of the speakers. This printed thing can be clipped on this slots and you can put some pens on it. In my case it worked very well. But please notice, that the small pieces can break if you handle it wrong and could get stuck on the slots.

When i buy a spare chain from my still chainsaw i get the chain in a cardboard box. When i use the chain in the field i realized the need of this thing. Sure you can by originals from still but what's the fun by having a 3d printer then.

To give this box a little extra a make some kind of counting system. There are 2 dials that have a small notch in it. In the box there is a pin with a small boll. I test fit this and with normal pla on 210 °c it is string enough and gives a nice tension on the dial. Whit this counter you can count the times that the chain is sharped or filed. So you have a idea whit spare chain is already used a lot and with is quit new.

There are 3 types of upper part . the one with " chain 40 cm file 4.8mm" on it. A other with "chain 35cm file 4mm" on it. The last one is without something.
The text is of course the chain length and with witch kind of file it need to sharp.
These are the only ones i own. If you like to have another text, just let me now.

assembling.:
mount the 2 counters in the wright place. Put a M3 bolt 25mm long in the hole and screw it thru the counters. At the other end place a M3 nut, there is a small place so normally the nut will self lock in the house. Do not tight this to strong or your counters while not rotate. For the hinge i drill/ clean the hole with a 2mm drill and then use a 1,75mm filament and melt it on both sides to fix it in place.

You can use the box also for other things.
If you have made one or you have some question just post it to me if you wan't.

Have fun.

Pay attention to print the pla warm enough. If you print it to low you have to weak layer bounding and you pins for the dials will brake of. I test it so you don't have to waste any plastic for it.
I print my piece at 210 or 215° Then the pins flex but don't brake easy.

title: Hephestos 2 - E3D/BLtouch/BQSensor Mount (Bowden)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is my E3D/BLTouch Mount for the BQ Hephestos 2 Printer.

Its printable without any Support. There are a few badass overhangs. But don't worry if your printer is well enough calibrated it's not an issue at all.

The Only File that needs some Support is the "E3DBLT_Heph2_RightGraft_V1.stl"

There are 2 holes covered by a 0.2mm Layer, in the "E3DBLT_Heph2_Carriage_V12.stl" to help to print it without support. So it's not an issue in the STL.



  • Installation: There is a pretty detailed installation Guide with Pictures. (Please follow it)
    The FANS can be mounted from the beginning or at the end doesn't matter.

  • DO NOT USE PLA since it will melt down at some spots. I recommend ABS but PETG should do it as well.

  • I am using Version 10 of the Mount as this release contains V12. With small improvements. I hope there is no issue since I never printed this Version. It should be okay. Just in case! xD

  • I only printed ABS with this Mount I never used the Part Cooling FAN. So I don't know if the FANDuct Position is properly given.



UPDATE1 / 28.2.18 : Added a Version for the BQ-Inductive Sensor. Using the same height as in the original Mount (not tested looking for a betatester)

Printer:

Hephestos 2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

15-30%

Notes:

Screws and Nuts



For each Screw is a Nut needed!

  • Part Cooling FAN to Carriage:
    3 x M3x20

  • Hotend FAN to Carriage:
    4 x M3x10 or 4 x M3x15 (depends on the FAN.)

  • BLTouch to Carriage:
    1 x M3x20
    1 x M3x15

  • Carriage to X-Axis:
    4 x M4x10

  • Hotend Fixer to Carriage:
    2 x M4x40


Firmware Values (BLTouch)
Probe Offsets:

#define X_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER -1 // X offset: -left +right [of the nozzle]
#define Y_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER 24 // Y offset: -front +behind [the nozzle]
#define Z_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER 0 // Z offset: -below +above [the nozzle]

Probe Boundaries: (Not optimized yet still using the olde values of the first unreleased prototypes of the mount)

#define LEFT_PROBE_BED_POSITION 30
#define RIGHT_PROBE_BED_POSITION 181
#define FRONT_PROBE_BED_POSITION 26
#define BACK_PROBE_BED_POSITION 270


Firmware Values (BQ Inductive Sensor)
Probe Offsets:

#define X_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER 28 // X offset: -left +right [of the nozzle]
#define Y_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER 16 // Y offset: -front +behind [the nozzle]
#define Z_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER 0 // Z offset: -below +above [the nozzle]

Probe Boundaries:

No Values since I am not using the BQ-Sensor. If someone uses this Mount and set it up might give me the right Values. I am too lazy to Calculate them myself atm :P


Clean the following Holes

Since I added a 0.2mmm layer on the holes you have to clean them with a 4mm Drill or similar tool. (This thin 0.2mm layer is included to print it without support)

Glue the E3DBLT_Heph2_BeltFixer_V12.stl in place!

Take care you glue it the right way in as you can see on the picture!

Insert M3-NUTS

After inserting the Nuts I locked them with a Screw and glued them with a 3D-Pen in place.
If you have no 3D-Pen take care to NOT glue the screw to the nut when using any glue.

Installing BLTouch

Before you install the BLTouch follow STEP1 and put the M4-Screws already in Place and lock them up with a nut from the other side. (It can be hard inserting those screws after installing the BLTouch)

STEP2
Install the BLTouch and lock it down with 2 x M3 Screws.
There is a little gap to put the Wires of the BLTouch to the top of the mount.

Insert the GT2-Belt in the BeltFixer

STEP1
Insert the Belt in the BeltFixer to get it easy done remove the belt on the motor side.
It can be a little laborious to do it. But its possible and once the belt is inserted it seats pretty tight.
STEP2
Be sure the lower part of the belt is inside the area you see in the picture when mounting the Carriage to the X-Axis.

Install the Carriage to the Axis

STEP1

If not already done remove the 2 temporal Nuts of the lower screws.

STEP2

Install the Carriage to the X-Axis with 4 x M4 Screws. The holes help you get access to the lower screws.

Important
**Be sure the lower part of the GT2 Belt is inside the X-Axis slide part.

Optional (Inserting Grafts)

If you like you can insert grafts into the holes to have the best Hotend FAN Airflow. Just put a little bit of glue at 2 points and put them in. Do not use too much otherwise you cannot remove them anymore.

Installing the Hotend

Insert the hotend from the bottom at a slight angle towards the front. Its pretty tight but should be easy to install.
After I had some problems to get it out after inserting the hotend, I increased the space in the front between the HE and the holes.

Insert M4-Nuts

Don't fix or glue those Nuts, since they fix the Hotend and need some tolerance.

Fix the Hotend

Fix the Hotend with E3DBLT_Heph2_HEFixer_V12.stl and 2 x M4x40 Screws

Take care when tightening the screws. Tight them alternately and do not tighten it too much. The HEFixer Part can be inserted 1mm deeper. To prevent a loose Hotend.

title: Axle spacer endcaps for Hope Pro 2 EVO rear hubs
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I'm constantly looking at my bikes and thinking "what else can I do with a 3D printer?"

Disclaimer: Just like everything else on Thingiverse, this is provided without any warranty, and if you don't feel comfortable actually using this printed part, then you probably shouldn't bother printing it. That said, I'm only printing parts that I feel are safe enough to put on my own bike.

This is my latest experiment... replacing the aluminum spacer endcaps on the Hope Pro 2 EVO rear hub with 3D printed parts. I've got the hub with a 142x12 through-axle setup, and I wanted to try that wheel on a bike with an older 135mm quick release rear axle. Thankfully with the Hope hubs it's just a matter of pulling off the endcaps and swapping them out, but I don't have the 135QR endcaps - so let's try printing them up!

I took a series of measurements from the existing aluminum 142x12 endcaps, and then replicated them in SketchUp. (I really need to learn FreeCAD or Fusion360 because dealing with the non-parametric modeling in SketchUp is annoying when small changes are needed) After I printed them up and checked fitting, I resized the 142x12 endcaps to work with a 135xQR axle. (10mm outer diameter in the dropouts with 5mm quick release skewer)
I also realized that I had a DT Swiss 10mm through-axle, so I printed that up (135x10mm) and am currently using that.

What happens if they fail?

When printing bike parts, the big thing to consider is what happens when they fail. These axle spacers aren't in simple compression like my fork lower crown race but they do still have an axle going through them in the case of the 142x12 through axle version, so worst case, they crush and the alignment of your gears or brake disk is off and the axle isn't tight. With a quick release you will lose tension in the skewer and the wheel will shift in the dropouts, with the possibility that it might hop out. Having the wheel hop out of the dropouts would be quite bad, but when I failed an early prototype accelerating hard on parts with less than 100% infill, the wheel just shifted and the tire dragging on the frame informed me that ride was over.

So yeah, if you print and use these and they fail, well, yeah, things can go badly. Up to you if you feel this is acceptable. For me on a bike I just cruise around town? Not a problem. Wouldn't take these parts on a cross-country trip or a downhill run.

Printer:

Monoprice Select mini

A bit more sturdy and easily printable design than the other tensioners i found for the cr10.

Also added is an experimental bracket that maybe fits smaller models CR10 that have a 20x40 center extrusion. I do not have that printer and can not check if this is at all suitable for that model printer, added it for anyone interested and willing to experiment.

No supports needed. Reuse the roller, but need new m4/m5 screws and Tnuts. This version is made for the more easily avalible m6 bolts for adjusting rather than m5 that other versions have. For a knob i simply scaled up 120% the knob from other designs.

I printed the main bracket standing vertical and the rider sitting flat. No changes to the rider so if you have the first model you can reuse it.
I have yet to actually print this as my machine is busy for a while, but it should fit as it uses the 20x20 extrusion.

title: GCMax Plug'N'Play GameCube HDMI and RGB Dongle

description.text:
This is the final case design for the GCMax project that I worked on with Dan Kunz (Citrus3000PSI)
I decided to take the a new approach on the case for the latest revision of the GCPlug project. Rather than having 4 separate pieces which make up the case I opted for making the case 2 pieces which attach with just two screws.
This case is not capable of being produced by a FDM printer, the entire case was designed with laser sintered nylon as the process for printing.
To complete the case you will need 2 M2x25mm flat head screws and 2 M2 nuts.
To complete the plug you will need a bare PCI connector(these can be found on ebay) as you will need to extract pins from the connector to insert into the plug.

Dan has shared his files and build instructions for the
PCB on OSHPark find them at this link: https://oshpark.com/shared_projects/UZZTO1KM

Please note that this project is not for the feint of heart, pining the connector is an arduous process, building the PCB will require exceptional skills with soldering.

Thank you Unseen for making all GCVideo based projects possible with your open source project.

description.text:
The Soviet RGD-33 (Ручная Граната Дьяконова образца 33 года >Ruchnaya Granata Djakonova obraztsa 33 goda, "Hand Grenade, Dyakonov design, pattern year [19]33") is an anti-personnel fragmentation stick grenade developed in 1933.

I designed this RGD-33 Grenade. Not exactly a replica, as optmized it for FDM 3d printing and for softair.

I cut Part1 into 3 pieces: A, B and C, for easy printing. (If you are printing on glass just print them and glue together)

Part1_C and Part4 should be grey
Part1_A, Part1_B, Part2 and Part3 should be green.

I hope you like the design and share your photos if you print it.

comments.text:
La idea es muy buena, pero el diseño no lo veo muy logico, no hay forma de separar la parte posterior de la delantera. El diseño tiene la pieza superior y la inferior, pero la "puerta trasera" no existe.
Aparte que por tamaño y por tiempo poca gente se animara. Hay que dividirlo en mas piezas o diseñarlo para que no sean mas de 140 horas imprimiendo.
comments.author: Ovejaveloz

comments.text:
No entiendo lo de la puerta. La primera versión tenía las bisagras cautivas, para no necesitar tornillos pero requería una capa más fina. (19 horas por pieza, 2 piezas. Imprescindible imprimir en vertical con la base hacia abajo)
Ahora he actualizado con una nueva versión con portafotos, base plana y bisagras abiertas (necesita pernos). Se imprime en dos piezas (más las argolla y el escudo) 14h cada una a 0,3 y 22% relleno. Imprescindible imprimir en vertical con la base hacia abajo. Saludos
comments.author: Ovejaveloz

comments.text:
A lo mejor es que no lo estoy viendo como es o como lo has pensado. En la segunda imagen se ve como si se abriese por detras mediante las bisagras, pero luego cuando cargo en cura los modelos, las bisagras son un bloque, y no se abre mediante dichas bisagras, parece como que la pieza superior encaja con la inferior mediante tornillos o algo similar. Lo mismo es efecto del cura y queda raro.
Ahora bajare la nueva version a ver como me aparece.
Por cierto, a mi me salian mas de 140 horas con 0,06 y un relleno del 70% que es lo que suelo usar, asi me parecia una burrada de tiempo.
comments.author: kurioso

comments.text: Un 70% de infill es demasiado para el 90% de los proyectos, sobre todo si no van a soportar cargas. Lo mismo para la altura de capa, para formas geométricas grandes (como esta caja) con un 0,20 tienes resolución de sobra.

author: smartdesign

description.text:
I love my Tronxy X1, it is just cheap and good, once you`ve modified it a bit, which to me was great fun.
I have not seen this particular solution anywhere (besides the under-box) so I guess this is really new :) The Tronxy is an elegant design but that elegance is quite rude undermined by its bulky and loose hanging electronics-box. I wanted it to be more compact, and so it went...
This is a frame in which to mount the controller board, organizes cables, along with a frontpanel that holds the display and buttons. As a very big bonus I managed to fit in a Raspberry as well to accomodate for an Octoprint server. Also a little frame was added to put in a dc-dc converter to supply the Raspi,
Before you get very enthousistic and all, a very big WARN ! In order to fit the the Raspberry I had to cut all the PIO-connector-pins and remove one of the double USB-connectors to have enough space under the printbed. So this option is less suited for the faint-of-hearts among us :)

Buttons in the front are from: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2266410

Have fun, leave your thoughts and comments...

Ps, some will notice that there is no usb-connection from the pi to the Melzi controller board. This is due to having big problems with the usb connection to the Pi. So I removed the serial usb-chip (CH340) from the Melzi and have connected serial straight to the PIO-serial pins of the Pi. No more usb-trouble and a great spacesaver as well.
